data.quote: To love what you do and feel that it matters-how could anything be more fun?
data.author: Katherine Graham

data.quote: When men are rightly occupied  their amusement grows out of their work  as the color-petals out of a fruitful flower.
data.author: John Ruskin

data.quote: When love and skill work together  expect a masterpiece.
data.author: John Ruskin

data.quote: Work consists of whatever a body is obliged to do  and play consists of whatever a body is not obliged to do.
data.author: Mark Twain

data.quote: Winning the [Nobel] prize wasn't half as exciting as doing the work itself.
data.author: Maria Goeppert Mayer

data.quote: Work and play are words used to describe the same thing under differing conditions.
data.author: Mark Twain

data.quote: When people go to work  they shouldn't have to leave their hearts at home.
data.author: Betty Bender

data.quote: Workaholics are energized rather than enervated by their work-their energy paradoxically expands as it is expended.
data.author: Marilyn Machlowitz

data.quote: The more I want to get something done  the less I call it work.
data.author: Richard Bach

data.quote: To deny we need and want power is to deny that we hope to be effective.
data.author: Liz Smith

data.quote: Success depends in a very large measure upon individual initiative and exertion  and cannot be achieved except by a dint of hard work.
data.author: Anna Pavlova

data.quote: Nothing worthwhile comes easily. Half effort does not produce half results  it produces no results. Work  continuous work and hard work  is the only way to accomplish results that last.
data.author: Hamilton Holt

data.quote: If a man wakes up famous  he hasn't been sleeping.
data.author: Wes Izzard

data.quote: Striving for success without hard work is like trying to harvest where you haven't planted.
data.author: David Bly

data.quote: If your dream is a big dream  and if you want your life to work on the high level that you say you do  there's no way around doing the work it takes to get you there.
data.author: Joyce Chapman

data.quote: Success is dependent on effort.
data.author: Sophocles

data.quote: Hard work has made it easy. That is my secret. That is why I win.
data.author: Nadia Comaneci

data.quote: Success comes before work only in the dictionary.
data.author: Anonymous

data.quote: Sweat plus sacrifice equals success.
data.author: Charles O. Finley

data.quote: The only thing that separates successful people from the ones who aren't is the willingness to work very  very hard.
data.author: Helen Gurley Brown

data.quote: You can have unbelievable intelligence  you can have connections  you can have opportunities fall out of the sky. But in the end  hard work is the true  enduring characteristic of successful people.
data.author: Marsha Evans

data.quote: Success usually comes to those who are too busy to be looking for it.
data.author: Henry David Thoreau

data.quote: In all human affairs there are efforts  there are results  and the strength of the effort is the measure of the result.
data.author: James Lane Allen

data.quote: Work  alternated with needful rest  is the salvation of man or woman.
data.author: Antoinette Brown Blackwell

data.quote: There is a time for work. And a time for love. That leaves no other time.
data.author: Coco Chanel

data.quote: Neither woman nor man lives by work  or love  alone.... The human self defines itself and grows through love and work: All psychology before and after Freud boils down to that.
data.author: Betty Friedan

data.quote: Maintain a good balance. A personal life adds dimensions to your professional life and vice versa. It helps nurture creativity through a deeper understanding of yourself.
data.author: Kathy Ireland

data.quote: For the happiest life  days should be rigorously planned  nights left open to chance.
data.author: Mignon McLaughlin

data.quote: Work is the province of cattle.
data.author: Dorothy Parker

data.quote: The only sin passion can commit is to be joyless.
data.author: Dorothy L. Sayers

data.quote: Skilled labor teaches something not to be found in books or in colleges.
data.author: Laura Towne

data.quote: Diligence is the mother of good luck  and God gives all things to industry.
data.author: Benjamin Franklin

data.quote: To industry  nothing is impossible.
data.author: Latin proverb

data.quote: I believe in hard work. It keeps the wrinkles out of the mind and spirit.
data.author: Helena Rubinstein

data.quote: God sells us all things at the price of labor.
data.author: Leonardo da Vinci

data.quote: The sport I love has taken me around the world and shown me many things.
data.author: Bonnie Blair

data.quote: I realized that with hard work  the world was your oyster. You could do anything you wanted to do. I learned that at a young age.
data.author: Chris Evert

data.quote: Fortune is ever seen accompanying industry.
data.author: Oliver Goldsmith

data.quote: Manual labor to my father was not only good and decent for its own sake  but as he was given to saying  it straightened out one's thoughts.
data.author: Mary Ellen Chase

data.quote: I get satisfaction of three kinds. One is creating something  one is being paid for it and one is the feeling that I haven't just been sitting on my ass all afternoon.
data.author: William F. Buckley

data.quote: The sentimentalist ages far more quickly than the person who loves his work and enjoys new challenges.
data.author: Lillie Langtry

data.quote: Busy people are never busybodies.
data.author: Ethel Watts Mumford

data.quote: What a man sows  that shall he and his relations reap.
data.author: Clarissa Graves

data.quote: The only way to enjoy anything in this life is to earn it first.
data.author: Ginger Rogers

data.quote: I have worked all my life  wanted to work all my life  needed to work all my life.
data.author: Liz Carpenter

data.quote: The simple idea that everyone needs a reasonable amount of challenging work in his or her life  and also a personal life  complete with noncompetitive leisure  has never really taken hold.
data.author: Judith Martin

data.quote: There is no more dreadful punishment than futile and hopeless labor.
data.author: Albert Camus

data.quote: Whether we call it a job or a career  work is more than just something we do. It is a part of who we are.
data.author: Anita Hill

data.quote: If I could I would always work in silence and obscurity  and let my efforts be known by their results.
data.author: Emily Bronte

data.quote: Nobody ever drowned in his own sweat.
data.author: Ann Landers

data.quote: The heights by great men reached and kept Were not attained by sudden flight  But they  while their companions slept  Were toiling upward in the night.
data.author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

data.quote: Work in some form or other is the appointed lot of all.
data.author: Anna Jameson

data.quote: Any man who has had the job I've had and didn't have a sense of humor wouldn't still be here.
data.author: Harry S. Truman

data.quote: Whatever the job you are asked to do at whatever level  do a good job because your reputation is your resume.
data.author: Madeleine Albright

data.quote: People should tell their children what life is all about-it's about work.
data.author: Lauren Bacall

data.quote: Marriage ain't easy but nothing that's worth much ever is.
data.author: Lillian Carter

data.quote: I don't think that work ever really destroyed anybody. I think that lack of work destroys them a hell of a lot more.
data.author: Katharine Hepburn

data.quote: For the last third of life there remains only work. It alone is always stimulating  rejuvenating  exciting and satisfying.
data.author: Kathe Kollwitz

data.quote: I slept  and dreamed that life was Beauty  I woke  and found that life was Duty.
data.author: Ellen Sturgis Hooper

data.quote: Passion is never enough  neither is skill.
data.author: Toni Morrison

data.quote: It's not the having  it's the getting.
data.author: Elizabeth Taylor

data.quote: Opportunity is missed by most people because it is dressed in overalls  and looks like work.
data.author: Thomas A. Edison

data.quote: A man's work is from sun to sun  but a mother's work is never done.
data.author: Anonymous

data.quote: Be strong! We are not here to play  to dream  to drift  We have hard work to do and loads to lift  Shun not the struggle-face it  'tis God's gift.
data.author: Maltbie D. Babcock

data.quote: If you could once make up your mind never to undertake more work ... than you can carry on calmly  quietly  without hurry or flurry ... and if the instant you feel yourself growing nervous and ... out of breath  you would stop and take a breath  you would find this simple common-sense rule doing for you what no prayers or tears could ever accomplish.
data.author: Elizabeth Prentiss

data.quote: It is better to have no emotion when it is work. Do what needs to be done  and do it coolly.
data.author: Louis L'Amour

data.quote: What a man accomplishes in a day depends upon the way in which he approaches his tasks. When we accept tough jobs as a challenge to our ability and wade into them with joy and enthusiasm  miracles can happen. When we do our work with a dynamic  conquering spirit  we get things done.
data.author: Arland Gilbert

data.quote: The one important thing I have learned over the years is the difference between taking one's work seriously  and taking one's self seriously. The first is imperative  and the second is disastrous.
data.author: Margot Fonteyn

data.quote: Work is the best method devised for killing time.
data.author: William Feather

data.quote: Industry is a better horse to ride than genius.
data.author: Walter Lippman

data.quote: There are two kinds of talents  man-made talent and God-given talent. With man-made talent you have to work very hard. With God-given talent  you just touch it up once in a while.
data.author: Pearl Bailey

data.quote: If you want something done  ask a busy person to do it. The more things you do  the more you can do.
data.author: Lucille Ball

data.quote: With the power of conviction  there is no sacrifice.
data.author: Pat Benatar

data.quote: I believe you are your work. Don't trade the stuff of your life  time  for nothing more than dollars. That's a rotten bargain
data.author: Rita Mae Brown

data.quote: When you're following your energy and doing what you want all the time  the distinction between work and play dissolves.
data.author: Shakti Gawain

data.quote: Work is the thing that stays. Work is the thing that sees us through.
data.author: Ellen Gilchrist

data.quote: Energy is the power that drives every human being. It is not lost by exertion but maintained by it  for it is a faculty of the psyche.
data.author: Germaine Greer

data.quote: It is not hard work that is dreary  it is superficial work
data.author: Edith Hamilton

data.quote: As for me  prizes mean nothing. My prize is my work.
data.author: Katharine Hepburn

data.quote: There can be no substitute for work  neither affection nor physical well-being can replace it.
data.author: Maria Montessori

data.quote: Work is its own cure. You have to like it better than being loved.
data.author: Marge Piercy

data.quote: Work ... has always been my favorite form of recreation.
data.author: Anna Howard Shaw

data.quote: A job is not a career. I think I started out with a job. It turned into a career and changed my life.
data.author: Barbara Walters

data.quote: The only genius that's worth anything is the genius for hard work.
data.author: Kathleen Winsor

data.quote: Elbow grease is the best polish.
data.author: English proverb

data.quote: Never despair  but if you do  work on in despair.
data.author: Edmund Burke

data.quote: Laziness is a secret ingredient that goes into failure. But it's only kept a secret from the person who fails.
data.author: Robert Half

data.quote: Pears cannot ripen alone. So we ripened together.
data.author: Meridel Le Sueur

data.quote: Ideally  couples need three lives  one for him  one for her  and one for them together.
data.author: Jacqueline Bisset

data.quote: Exchange is creation.
data.author: Muriel Rukeyser

data.quote: Whatever my individual desires were to be free  I was not alone. There were others who felt the same way.
data.author: Rosa Parks

data.quote: Now men and women are separate and unequal. We should be hand in hand  in fact  we should have our arms around one another.
data.author: Cloris Leachman

data.quote: Men and women are like right and left hands: it doesn't make sense not to use both.
data.author: Jeannette Rankin

data.quote: There are three ways of dealing with difference: domination  compromise  and integration. By domination only one side gets what it wants  by compromise neither side gets what it wants  by integration we find a way by which both sides may get what they wish.
data.author: Mary Parker Follett

data.quote: Women and men have to fight together to change society-and both will benefit.
data.author: Muriel Fox

data.quote: Every time a man unburdens his heart to a stranger he reaffirms the love that unites humanity.
data.author: Germaine Greer

data.quote: Good communication is as stimulating as black coffee  and just as hard to sleep after.
data.author: Anne Morrow Lindbergh

data.quote: Cooperation is an intelligent functioning of the concept of laissez faire-a thorough conviction that nobody can get there unless everybody gets there.
data.author: Virginia Burden Tower

data.quote: Most leaders are indispensable  but to produce a major social change  many ordinary people must also be involved.
data.author: Anne Firor Scott

data.quote: Communication is a continual balancing act  juggling the conflicting needs for intimacy and independence. To survive in the world  we have to act in concert with others  but to survive as ourselves  rather than simply as cogs in a wheel  we have to act alone.
data.author: Deborah Tannen

data.quote: My whole life  whether it be long or short  shall be devoted to your service and the service of our great imperial family to which we all belong. But I shall not have the strength to carry out this resolution alone unless you join in it with me.
data.author: Queen Elizabeth II

data.quote: A person who believes ... that there is a whole of which one is a part  and that in being a part one is whole: such a person has no desire whatever  at any time  to play God. Only those who have denied their being yearn to play at it.
data.author: Ursula K. LeGuin

data.quote: Unless I am a part of everything I am nothing.
data.author: Penelope Lively

data.quote: For what is done or learned by one class of women becomes  by virtue of their common womanhood  the property of all women.
data.author: Elizabeth Blackwell

data.quote: We learn best to listen to our own voices if we are listening at the same time to other women-whose stories  for all our differences  turn out  if we listen well  to be our stories also.
data.author: Barbara Deming

data.quote: Remember the dignity of your womanhood. Do not appeal  do not beg  do not grovel. Take courage  join hands  stand beside us  fight with us.
data.author: Christabel Pankhurst

data.quote: Today whenever women gather together it is not necessarily nurturing. It is coalition building. And if you feel the strain  you may be doing some good work.
data.author: Bernice Johnson Reagon

data.quote: Women's art  though created in solitude  wells up out of community. There is  clearly  both enormous hunger for the work thus being diffused  and an explosion of creative energy  bursting through the coercive choicelessness of the system on whose boundaries we are working.
data.author: Adrienne Rich

data.quote: You've got to be willing to stay committed to someone over the long run  and sometimes it doesn't work out. But often if you become real honest with yourself and honest with each other  and put aside whatever personal hurt and disappointment you have to really understand yourself and your spouse  it can be the most wonderful experience you've ever had.
data.author: Hillary Rodham Clinton

data.quote: We must stand together  if we don't  there will be no victory for any one of us.
data.author: Mother Jones

data.quote: I've always believed that one woman's success can only help another woman's success.
data.author: Gloria Vanderbilt

data.quote: Alone we can do so little  together we can do so much.
data.author: Helen Keller

data.quote: I always feel the movement is a sort of mosaic. Each of us puts in one little stone  and then you get a great mosaic at the end.
data.author: Alice Paul

data.quote: We all act as hinges-fortuitous links between other people.
data.author: Penelope Lively

data.quote: We seldom stop to think how many people's lives are entwined with our own. It is a form of selfishness to imagine that every individual can operate on his own or can pull out of the general stream and not be missed.
data.author: Ivy Baker Priest

data.quote: When Adam dolve  and Eve span  Who was then the gentleman?
data.author: John Ball

data.quote: Better to wear out than to rust out.
data.author: Bishop Cumberland

data.quote: The workers are the saviors of society  the redeemers of the race.
data.author: Eugene V. Debs

data.quote: Handle your tools without mittens.
data.author: Benjamin Franklin

data.quote: Tools were made and born were hands  Every farmer understands.
data.author: William Blake

data.quote: I never did anything worth doing by accident  nor did any of my inventions come by accident  they came by work.
data.author: Thomas Alva Edison

data.quote: It's all in the day's work.
data.author: English Saying

data.quote: A ploughman on his legs is higher than a gentleman on his knees.
data.author: Benjamin Franklin

data.quote: In the sweat of thy face shalt thou eat bread.
data.author: Bible

data.quote: All work and no play makes Jack a dull boy.
data.author: James Howell

data.quote: I like work  it fascinates me. I can sit and look at it for hours. I love to keep it by me: the idea of getting rid of it nearly breaks my heart.
data.author: Jerome K. Jerome

data.quote: And only the Master shall praise us  and only the Master shall blame  And no one shall work for money  and no one shall work for fame  But each for the joy of the working  and each  in his separate star  Shall draw the Thing as he sees It  for the God of things as They Are!
data.author: Rudyard Kipling

data.quote: No man is born into the world whose work Is not born with him  there is always work  And tools to work withal  for those who will  And blessed are the horny hands of toil!
data.author: James Russell Lowell

data.quote: The laborer is worthy of his hire.
data.author: Bible

data.quote: How many a rustic Milton has passed by  Stifling the speechless longings of his heart  In unremitting drudgery and care! How many a vulgar Cato has compelled His energies  no longer tameless then  To mould a pin  or fabricate a nail!
data.author: Percy Bysshe Shelley

data.quote: Many hands make light work.
data.author: William Patten

data.quote: Heaven is blessed with perfect rest but the blessing of earth is toil.
data.author: Henry Van Dyke

data.quote: This is the best world  that we live in  To lend and to spend and to give in: But to borrow  or beg  or to get a man's own  It is the worst world that ever was known.
data.author: Anonymous

data.quote: This world's a bubble.
data.author: Sir Francis Bacon

data.quote: Believe everything you hear said of the world  nothing is too impossibly bad.
data.author: Honore de Balzac

data.quote: The world is like a board with holes in it  and the square men have got into the round holes  and the round into the square.
data.author: Bishop Berkeley

data.quote: The pomps and vanity of this wicked world.
data.author: Bible

data.quote: But in this world nothing is sure but death and taxes.
data.author: Benjamin Franklin

data.quote: The year's at the Spring And day's at the morn  Morning's at seven  The hillside's dew-pearled  The lark's on the wing  The snail's on the thorn: God's in his Heaven -  All's right with the world!
data.author: Elizabeth Barrett Browning

data.quote: I have not loved the world  nor the world me  I have not flatter'd its rank breath  nor bow'd To its idolatries a patient knee.
data.author: Lord Byron

data.quote: Socrates  indeed  when he was asked of what country he called himself  said  "Of the world"  for he considered himself an inhabitant and a citizen of the whole world.
data.author: Cicero

data.quote: Such stuff the world is made of.
data.author: William Cowper

data.quote: Come  follow me  and leave the world to its babblings.
data.author: Dante Alighieri

data.quote: Good-bye  proud world! I'm going home  Thou are not my friend  I am not thine.
data.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

data.quote: But it does move.
data.author: Galileo

data.quote: The world is a beautiful book  but of little use to him who cannot read it.
data.author: Carlo Goldoni

data.quote: The nations are as a drop of a bucket.
data.author: Isaiah

data.quote: World without end.
data.author: Isaiah

data.quote: It takes all sorts of people to make a world.
data.author: Douglas Jerrold

data.quote: If there is one beast in all the loathsome fauna of civilization I hate and despise it is a man of the world.
data.author: Henry Arthur Jones

data.quote: The world is God's world  after all.
data.author: Charles Kingsley

data.quote: The world goes up and the world goes down  And the sunshine follows the rain  And yesterday's sneer and yesterday's frown Can never come over again  Sweet wife. No  never come over again.
data.author: Charles Kingsley

data.quote: You'll never have a quiet world till you knock the patriotism out of the human race.
data.author: George Bernard Shaw

data.quote: If all the world must see the world As the world the world hath seen  Then it were better for the world That the world had never been.
data.author: Charles C. Leland

data.quote: The world is full of beauty  as other worlds above  And if we did our duty  it might be as full of love.
data.author: Gerald Massey

data.quote: This world is all a fleeting show  For man's illusion given  The smiles of joy  the tears of woe  Deceitful shine  deceitful flow  -  There's nothing true but Heaven.
data.author: George Moore

data.quote: Half the world does not know how the other half lives.
data.author: Francois Rabelais

data.quote: All the world's a stage  And all the men and women merely players.
data.author: William Shakespeare

data.quote: Why  then  the world's mine oyster  Which I with sword will open.
data.author: William Shakespeare

data.quote: This world surely is wide enough to hold both thee and me.
data.author: Laurence Sterne

data.quote: There was all the world and his wife.
data.author: Jonathan Swift

data.quote: A mad world  my masters.
data.author: John Taylor

data.quote: So many worlds  so much to do  So little done  such things to be.
data.author: Lord Alfred Tennyson

data.quote: Everything is for the best in this best of all possible worlds.
data.author: Voltaire

data.quote: This world is a comedy to those who think  a tragedy to those who feel.
data.author: Horace Walpole

data.quote: Worry affects the circulation  the heart  the glands  the whole nervous system  and profoundly affects the health. You have never known a man who died from overwork  but many who died from doubt.
data.author: Charles W. Mayo

data.quote: Everybody knows if you are too careful you are so occupied in being careful that you are sure to stumble over something.
data.author: Gertrude Stein

data.quote: Worry is a god  invisible but omnipotent. It steals the bloom from the cheek and lightness from the pulse  it takes away the appetite  and turns the hair gray.
data.author: Benjamin Disraeli

data.quote: A worried man could borrow a lot of trouble with practically no collateral.
data.author: Helen Nielsen

data.quote: If your eyes are blinded with your worries  you cannot see the beauty of the sunset.
data.author: Jiddu Krishnamurti

data.quote: Worry often gives a small thing a big shadow.
data.author: Swedish proverb

data.quote: If you worry about what might be  and wonder what might have been  you will ignore what is.
data.author: Anonymous

data.quote: Bacteria and other microorganisms find it easier to infect people who worry and fret.
data.author: Leo Rangell

data.quote: Worry is a funky luxury when a lot has to be done.
data.author: Melvin Peebles

data.quote: Worries are the most stubborn habits in the world. Even after a poor man has won a huge lottery prize  he will still for months wake up in the night with a start  worrying about food and rent.
data.author: Vicki Baum

data.quote: There is nothing so wretched or foolish as to anticipate misfortunes. What madness is it in expecting evil before it arrives?
data.author: Marcus Annaeus Seneca

data.quote: Worry is like racing the engine of an automobile without letting in the clutch.
data.author: Corrie ten Boom

data.quote: Worry is evidence of an ill-controlled brain  it is merely a stupid waste of time in unpleasantness.
data.author: Arnold Bennett

data.quote: It ain't no use putting up your umbrella till it rains!
data.author: Alice Caldwell Rice

data.quote: When speculation has done its worst  two and two still make four.
data.author: Samuel Johnson

data.quote: Worry a little bit every day and in a lifetime you will lose a couple of years. If something is wrong  fix it if you can. But train yourself not to worry. Worry never fixes anything.
data.author: Mary Hemingway

data.quote: Worry is like a rocking chair-it keeps you moving but doesn't get you anywhere.
data.author: Corrie ten Boom

data.quote: Anxiety is the poison of human life  the parent of many sins and of more miseries.... Can it alter the cause  or unravel the mystery of human events?
data.author: Paxton Blair

data.quote: It only seems as if you are doing something when you're worrying.
data.author: L. M. Montgomery

data.quote: A hundredload of worry will not pay an ounce of debt.
data.author: George Herbert

data.quote: Worry is a futile thing  it's somewhat like a rocking chair  Although is keeps you occupied  it doesn't get you anywhere.
data.author: Anonymous

data.quote: Worry never climbed a hill  worry never paid a bill  Worry never dried a tear  worry never calmed a fear  Worry never darned a heel  worry never cooked a meal  It never led a horse to water  nor ever did a thing it "oughter."
data.author: Anonymous

data.quote: I am reminded of the advice of my neighbor. "Never worry about your heart 'til it stops beating."
data.author: E. B. White

data.quote: Worry is as useless as a handle on a snowball.
data.author: Mitzi Chandler

data.quote: When you worry  you go over the same ground endlessly and come out the same place you started. Thinking  on the other hand  makes progress from one place to another. ... The problem of life is to change worry into thinking  and anxiety into creative action.
data.author: Harold B. Walker

data.quote: Which of you by being anxious can add one cubit unto his stature?
data.author: Bible

data.quote: I think these difficult times have helped me to understand better than before how infinitely rich and beautiful life is in every way  and that so many things that one goes around worrying about are of no importance whatsoever.
data.author: Isak Dinesen

data.quote: You always get negative reactions. If you worry about that  you would never do anything.
data.author: Tom Monaghan

data.quote: Anxiety never yet successfully bridged any chasm.
data.author: Giovanni Ruffini

data.quote: Cast away care  he that loves sorrow lengthens not a day  nor can he buy tomorrow.
data.author: Thomas Dekker

data.quote: Worry doesn't help tomorrow's troubles  but it does ruin today's happiness.
data.author: Anonymous

data.quote: You can't start worrying about what's going to happen. You get spastic enough worrying about what's happening now.
data.author: Lauren Bacall

data.quote: There are two days in the week about which and upon which I never worry. ... One of these days is Yesterday ... And the other day I do not worry about is Tomorrow.
data.author: Robert Jones Burdette

data.quote: We have to fight them daily  like fleas  those many small worries about the morrow  for they sap our energies.
data.author: Etty Hillesum

data.quote: T'ain't worthwhile to wear a day all out before it comes.
data.author: Sarah Orne Jewett

data.quote: Worry never robs tomorrow of its sorrow  but only saps today of its strength.
data.author: A. J. Cronin

data.quote: The really frightening thing about middle age is that you know you'll grow out of it!
data.author: Doris Day

data.quote: Be  therefore  not anxious about tomorrow  for tomorrow will be anxious for the things of itself.
data.author: Bible

data.quote: Never despair  but if you do  work on in despair.
data.author: Edmund Burke

data.quote: If you are doing your best  you will not have time to worry about failure.
data.author: Robert Hillyer

data.quote: It is not work that kills men  it is worry. Work is healthy  you can hardly put more upon a man that he can bear. Worry is rust upon the blade.
data.author: Henry Ward Hughes

data.quote: No good work is ever done while the heart is hot and anxious and fretted.
data.author: Olive Schreiner

data.quote: A day of worry is more exhausting than a day of work.
data.author: John Lubbock

data.quote: The reason why worry kills more people than work is that more people worry than work.
data.author: Robert Frost

data.quote: Worry is a form of fear.
data.author: Bertrand A. Russell

data.quote: Worry is a complete cycle of inefficient thought revolving about a pivotal fear.
data.author: Anonymous

data.quote: Worry is a state of mind based on fear.
data.author: Napoleon Hill

data.quote: Worry is a thin stream of fear trickling through the mind. If encouraged  it cuts a channel into which all other thoughts are drained.
data.author: Arthur Somers Roche

data.quote: If we would keep filling our minds with the picture of happy things ahead  many worries and anxieties  and perhaps ill health  would naturally melt away.... Always expect the best. Would you sell both your eyes for a million dollars ... or your two legs ... or your hands ... or your hearing? data.quote: Accept that all of us can be hurt  that all of us can-and surely will at times-fail. Other vulnerabilities  like being embarrassed or risking love  can be terrifying  too. I think we should follow a simple rule: if we can take the worst  take the risk.

data.quote: When you're a writer  you no longer see things with the freshness of the normal person. He wants to be terribly human  and he responds emotionally  but at the same time there's this cold observer who cannot cry.

data.quote: When I am dead  I hope it may be said: 'His sins were scarlet  but his books were read.'

data.quote: The best part of every author is in general to be found in his book  I assure you.
data.author: Samuel Johnson

data.quote: The obscurity of a writer is generally in proportion to his incapacity.
data.author: Quintilian

data.quote: Life cannot defeat a writer who is in love with writing - for life itself is a writer's love until death.
data.author: Edna Ferber

data.quote: Just get it down on paper  and then we'll see what to do with it.
data.author: Maxwell Perkins

data.quote: Advice to young writers who want to get ahead without any annoying delays: don't write about Man  write about a man.
data.author: E. B. White

data.quote: Vigorous writing is concise. A sentence should contain no unnecessary words  a paragraph no unnecessary sentences  for the same reason that a drawing should have no unnecessary lines and a machine no unnecessary parts. This requires not that the writer make all his sentences short  or that he avoid all detail and treat his subjects only in outline  but that every word tell.

data.quote: Tennessee Williams said if he got rid of his demons  he would lose his angels.

data.quote: Self-expression is for babies and seals  where it can be charming. A writer's business is to affect the reader.

data.quote: There is but one art  to omit.

data.quote: A man really writes for an audience of about ten persons. Of course if others like it  that is clear gain. But if those ten are satisfied  he is content.

data.quote: It is in the hard rockpile labour of seeking to win  hold  or deserve a reader's interest that the pleasant agony of writing comes in.

data.quote: Write something  even if it's just a suicide note.
data.author: Anonymous

data.quote: Flaubert had infinite correction to perform.
data.author: Roland Barthes

data.quote: Nature  not content with denying him the ability to think  has endowed him with the ability to write.
data.author: A. E. Housman

data.quote: Beauty and truth may be attributes of good writing  but if the writer deliberately aims at truth  he is likely to find that what he has hit is the didactic.

data.quote: When an author is yet living  we estimate his powers by his worst performance  and when he is dead  we rate them by his best.

data.quote: How vain it is to sit down to write when you have not stood up to live.

data.quote: A writer is someone who can make a riddle out of an answer.

data.quote: The man who is asked by an author what he thinks of his work is put to the torture and is not obliged to speak the truth.

data.quote: Style is the hallmark of a temperament stamped upon the material at hand.

data.quote: Every writer  without exception  is a masochist  a sadist  a peeping Tom  an exhibitionist  a narcissist  an injustice collector and a depressed person constantly haunted by fears of unproductivity.

data.quote: My novels point out that the world consists entirely of exceptions.

data.quote: Less is more.
data.author: Robert Browning

data.quote: We like that a sentence should read as if its author  had he held a plough instead of a pen  could have drawn a furrow deep and straight to the end.
data.author: Henry David Thoreau

data.quote: The reason a writer writes a book is to forget a book and the reason a reader reads one is to remember it.

data.quote: I work every day - or at least I force myself into office or room. I may get nothing done  but you don't earn bonuses without putting in time. Nothing may come for three months  but you don't earn the fourth without it.

data.quote: John the Baptist pretending to be Karl Marx.
data.author: Anonymous

data.quote: Every word she writes is a lie  including 'and' and 'the'.

data.quote: When you put down the good things you ought to have done  and leave out the bad things you did do - well  that's memoirs.

data.quote: Journalism allows it's readers to witness history. Fiction gives its readers an opportunity to live it.

data.quote: His (the writer's) standard of fidelity to the truth should be so high that his invention  out of his experience  should produce a truer account than anything factual can be.

data.quote: The most lasting reputation I have is for an almost ferocious aggressiveness  when in fact I am amiable  indulgent  affectionate  shy and rather timid at heart.
data.author: J. B. Priestley

data.quote: The life of a writer is tragic: the more we advance  the farther there is to go and the more there is to say  the less time there is to say it.
data.author: Gabrielle Roy

data.quote: It is only through fiction and the dimension of the imaginary that we can learn something real about individual experience. Any other approach is bound to be general and abstract.

data.quote: When the style is fully formed  if it has a sweet undersong  we call it beautiful  and the writer may do what he likes in words or syntax.

data.quote: I have only made this letter rather long because I have not had time to make it shorter.
data.author: Blaise Pascal

data.quote: It makes a great difference in the force of a sentence whether a man be behind it or no.

data.quote: Footnotes  the little dogs yapping at the heels of the text.
data.author: William James

data.quote: I like prefaces. I read them. Sometimes I do not read any further.
data.author: Malcolm Lowry

data.quote: As for style of writing  if one has anything to say  it drops from him simply and directly  as a stone falls to the ground.
data.author: Henry David Thoreau

data.quote: What is written without effort is in general read without pleasure.
data.author: Samuel Johnson

data.quote: Proper words in proper places  make the true definition of a style.
data.author: Jonathan Swift

data.quote: They're fancy talkers about themselves  writers. If I had to give young writers advice  I would say don't listen to writers talking about writing or themselves.
data.author: Lillian Hellman

data.quote: The business of writing is one of the four or five most private things in the world.
data.author: Ethel Wilson

data.quote: I conceive that the right way to write a story for boys is to write so that it will not only interest boys but strongly interest any man who has ever been a boy. That immensely enlarges the audience.
data.author: Mark Twain

data.quote: He claimed his modest share of the general foolishness of the human race.
data.author: Irving Howe

data.quote: There are two kinds of writers - the great ones who can give you truths  and the lesser ones  who can only give you themselves.
data.author: Clifton Fadiman

data.quote: My own experience is that once a story has been written  one has to cross out the beginning and the end. It is there that we authors do most of our lying . . . one must ruthlessly suppress everything that is not concerned with the subject. If  in the first chapter  you say there is a gun hanging on the wall  you should make quite sure that it is going to be used further on in the story.
data.author: Anton Chekhov

data.quote: (Writing) - the art of applying the seat of the pants to the seat of the chair.
data.author: Mary Heaton Worse

data.quote: All a writer has to do to get a woman is to say he's a writer. It's an aphrodisiac.
data.author: Saul Bellow

data.quote: Publication is a self-invasion of privacy.
data.author: Marshall McLuhan

data.quote: It has been said that writing comes more easily if you have something to say.
data.author: Sholem Asch

data.quote: I've put my genius into my life  I've only put my talent into my works.
data.author: Oscar Wilde

data.quote: Fundamentally  all writing is about the same thing: it's about dying  about the brief flicker of time we have here  and the frustrations that it creates.
data.author: Mordecai Richler

data.quote: I am what libraries and librarians have made me  with a little assistance from a professor of Greek and a few poets.
data.author: B. K. Sandwell

data.quote: Our society  like decadent Rome  has turned into an amusement society  with writers chief among the court jesters - not so much above the clatter as part of it.
data.author: Saul Bellow

data.quote: If you would be a reader  read  if a writer  write.
data.author: Epictetus

data.quote: A writer and nothing else: a man alone in a room with the English language  trying to get human feelings right.
data.author: John K. Hutchens

data.quote: How can I know what I think till I see what I say?
data.author: E. M. Forster

data.quote: Please  never despise the translator. He's the mailman of human civilization.
data.author: Alexander Pushkin

data.quote: The waste basket is a writer's best friend.
data.author: Isaac Bashevis Singer

data.quote: The llama is a woolly sort of fleecy hairy goat With an indolent expression and an undulating throat - Like an unsuccessful literary man.
data.author: Hilaire Belloc

data.quote: If a man means his writing seriously  he must mean to write well. But how can he write well until he learns to see what he has written badly. His progress toward good writing and his recognition of bad writing are bound to unfold at something like the same rate.

data.quote: Words and sentences are subjects of revision  paragraphs and whole compositions are subjects of prevision.
data.author: Barrett Wendell

data.quote: There is nothing more dangerous to the formation of a prose style than the endeavour to make it poetic.
data.author: J. Middleton Murry

data.quote: The most original thing a writer can do is write like himself. It is also his most difficult task.

data.quote: Now as through this world I ramble  I see lots of funny men  Some rob you with a six gun Some with a fountain pen.
data.author: Woody Guthrie

data.quote: It is the function of art to renew our perception. What we are familiar with we cease to see. The writer shakes up the familiar scene  and  as if by magic  we see a new meaning in it.
data.author: Anais Nin

data.quote: A woman must have money and a room of her own if she is to write fiction.
data.author: Virginia Woolf

data.quote: Better to write for yourself and have no public  than to write for the public and have no self.
data.author: Cyril Connolly

data.quote: I have cultivated my hysteria with joy and terror.
data.author: Charles Baudelaire

data.quote: Writing has power  but its power has no vector. Writers can stir the mind  but they can't direct it. Time changes things  God changes things  the dictators change things  but writers can't change anything.
data.author: Isaac Bashevis Singer

data.quote: A good writer is basically a story-teller  not a scholar or a redeemer of mankind.
data.author: Isaac Bashevis Singer

data.quote: Anybody can find out if he is a writer. If he were a writer  when he tried to write of some particular day  he would find in the effort that he could recall exactly how the light fell and how the temperature felt  and all the quality of it. Most people cannot do it. If they can do it  they may never be successful in a pecuniary sense  but that ability is at the bottom of writing  I am sure.
data.author: Maxwell Perkins

data.quote: I believe the writer... should always be the final judge. I have always held to that position and have sometimes seen books hurt thereby  but at least as often helped. The book belongs to the author.
data.author: Maxwell Perkins

data.quote: You have to throw yourself away when you write.
data.author: Maxwell Perkins

data.quote: A memorandum is written to protect the writer - not to inform his reader.
data.author: Dean Acheson

data.quote: I write for myself and strangers. The strangers  dear Readers  are an afterthought.
data.author: Gertrude Stein

data.quote: The great enemy of clear language is insincerity. When there is a gap between one's real and one's declared aims  one turns as if it were instinctively to long words and exhausted idioms  like a cuttlefish squirting out ink.

data.quote: A novel must be exceptionally good to live as long as the average cat.
data.author: Hugh MacLennan

data.quote: You praise the firm restraint with which they write - I'm with you  there  of course: They use the snaffle and the curb all right  But where's the bloody horse?
data.author: Roy Campbell

data.quote: At least half the mystery novels published violate the law that the solution  once revealed  must seem to be inevitable.
data.author: Raymond Chandler

data.quote: On the trail of another man  the biographer must put up with finding himself at every turn: any biography uneasily shelters an autobiography within it.

data.quote: The editorial job has become  unlike the ancient age when one judged what one read  a job of making judgements on outlines  ideas  reputations  previous books  scenarios  treatments  talk and promises.

data.quote: An editor should tell the author his writing is better than it is. Not a lot better  a little better.

data.quote: Writing is a solitary occupation. Family  friends and society are the natural enemies of a writer. He must be alone  uninterrupted and slightly savage if he is to sustain and complete an undertaking.

data.quote: Just as there is nothing between the admirable omelette and the intolerable  so with autobiography.
data.author: Hilaire Belloc

data.quote: How can you write if you can't cry?
data.author: Ring Lardner

data.quote: I think it's bad to talk about one's present work  for it spoils something at the root of the creative act. It discharges the tension.

data.quote: As for my next book  I am going to hold myself from writing it till I have it impending in me: grown heavy in my mind like a ripe pear  pendant  gravid  asking to be cut or it will fall.

data.quote: No man understands a deep book until he has seen and lived at least part of its contents.

data.quote: Writing is easy: all you do is sit staring at the blank sheet of paper until the drops of blood form on your forehead.

data.quote: Your manuscript is both good and original  but the parts that are good are not original  and the parts that are original are not good.

data.quote: The reason why so few good books are written is that so few people who can write know anything.

data.quote: Whatever we conceive well we express clearly.
data.author: Nicolas Boileau

data.quote: Talent alone cannot make a writer. There must be a man behind the book.

data.quote: Think much  speak little  and write less.

data.quote: A man may write himself out of reputation when nobody else can do it.

data.quote: The multitude is always in the wrong.

data.quote: Two wrongs do not make a right.

data.quote: Truth forever on the scaffold  wrong forever on the throne.

data.quote: The remedy for wrongs is to forget them.

data.quote: Blessed are the young  for they shall inherit the national debt.

data.quote: When a man of 40 falls in love with a girl of 20  it isn't her youth he is seeking but his own.

data.quote: Young folk  silly folk  old folk  cold folk.

data.quote: Much may be made of a Scotchman if he be caught young.

data.quote: Young men think old men fools and old men know young men to be so.

data.quote: It takes a long time to become young.

data.quote: The belief that youth is the happiest time of life is founded upon a fallacy. The happiest person is the person who thinks the most interesting thoughts  and we grow happier as we grow older.

data.quote: When I was a boy of fourteen  my father was so ignorant I could hardly stand to have the old man around. But when I got to be twenty-one  I was astonished at how much the old man had learned in seven years.

data.quote: It is essential that we enable young people to see themselves as participants in one of the most exciting eras in history  and to have a sense of purpose in relation to it.

data.quote: Oh  to be only half as wonderful as my child thought I was when he was small  and only half as stupid as my teenager now thinks I am.

data.quote: When I was younger  I could remember anything  whether it had happened or not.

data.quote: The deepest definition of youth is life as yet untouched by tragedy.

data.quote: Only the young die good.
data.author: Oliver Herford

data.quote: I am constantly amazed when I talk to young people to learn how much they know about sex and how little about soap.

data.quote: The joy of the young is to disobey - but the trouble is that there are no longer any orders.

data.quote: To keep clear of concealment  to keep clear of the need of concealment  to do nothing that he might not do out on the middle of Boston Common at noonday -I cannot say how more and more that seems to me to be the glory of a young man's life. It is an awful hour when the first necessity of hiding anything comes. The whole life is different thenceforth. When there are questions to be feared and eyes to be avoided and subjects that must not be touched  then the bloom of life is gone. Put off that day as long as possible. Put if off forever if you can.
data.author: Phillips Brooks

data.quote: Youth has become a class.

data.quote: The 'teenager' seems to have replaced the Communist as the appropriate target for public controversy and foreboding.

data.quote: Everyone believes in his youth that the world really began with him  and that all merely exists for his sake.

data.quote: It is not possible for civilization to flow backward while there is youth in the world. Youth may be headstrong  but it will advance its allotted length.

data.quote: You never see the old austerity That was the essence of civility  Young people hereabouts  unbridled  now Just want.

data.quote: The young always have the same problem - how to rebel and conform at the same time. They have now solved this by defying their parents and copying one another.

data.quote: One boy's a boy  two boys are half a boy  three boys are no boy at all.

data.quote: I do beseech you to direct your efforts more to preparing youth for the path and less to preparing the path for the youth.

data.quote: Every generation is a secret society and has incommunicable enthusiasms  tastes  and interests which are a mystery both to its predecessors and to posterity.

data.quote: The interests of childhood and youth are the interests of mankind.

data.quote: The youth gets together this material to build a bridge to the moon  or perchance  a palace or temple on earth  and at length  the middle-aged man concludes to build a woodshed with them.

data.quote: Don't laugh at a youth for his affectations  he's only trying on one face after another till he finds his own.

data.quote: It's all that the young can do for the old  to shock them and keep them up to date.

data.quote: What though youth gave love and roses Age still leaves us friends and wine.
data.author: Thomas More

data.quote: In the lexicon of youth  which fate reserves For a bright manhood  there is no such word As fail.
data.author: Edward G. Bulwer-Lytton

data.quote: Ah! happy years! once more who would not be a boy!

data.quote: As I approve of a youth that has something of the old man in him  so I am no less pleased with an old man that has something of the youth. He that follows this rule may be old in body  but can never be so in mind.

data.quote: I remember my youth and the feeling that will never come back any more - the feeling that I could last forever  outlast the sea  the earth  and all men.

data.quote: Reckless youth makes rueful age.

data.quote: In youth we learn  in age we understand.
data.author: Marie von Ebner-Eschenbach

data.quote: Youth will be served.
data.author: English proverb

data.quote: Forty is the old age of youth  fifty is the youth of old age.
data.author: French proverb

data.quote: Yes  you may depend upon it he has the ability! He is the younger generation that stands ready to knock at my door - to make an end of Halvard Solness.
data.author: Henrik Ibsen

data.quote: Youth! youth! how buoyant are thy hopes  they turn  Like marigolds  toward the sunny side.
data.author: Jean Ingelow

data.quote: All the world's a mass of folly  Youth is gay  age melancholy: Youth is spending  age is thrifty  Mad at twenty  cold at fifty  Man is nought but folly's slave  From the cradle to the grave.

data.quote: Your old men shall dream dreams  your young men shall see visions.
data.author: Bible

data.quote: Youth comes but once in a lifetime.
data.author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

data.quote: How beautiful is youth! how bright it gleams With its illusions  aspirations  dreams! Book of Beginnings  Story without End  Each maid a heroine  and each man a friend!
data.author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

data.quote: We think our fathers fools  so wise we grow  Our wiser sons  no doubt  will think us so.
data.author: Alexander Pope

data.quote: If youth but knew  and age were able  Then poverty would be a fable.
data.author: Proverbs

data.quote: Keep true to the dreams of thy youth.
data.author: Friedrich von Schiller

data.quote: Ah sorts of allowances are made for the illusions of youth  and none  or almost none  for the disenchantments of age.

data.quote: Crabbed age and youth cannot live together  Youth is full of pleasure  age is full of care  Youth like summer morn  age like winter weather  Youth like summer brave  age like winter bare. Youth is full sport  age's breath is short  Youth is nimble  age is lame  Youth is hot and bold  age is weak and cold  Youth is wild  age is tame. Age  I do abhor thee  youth  I do adore thee.
data.author: William Shakespeare

data.quote: For God's sake give me the young man who has brains enough to make a fool of himself.
data.author: Robert Louis Stevenson

data.quote: Live as long as you may  the first twenty years are the longest half of your life.
data.author: Robert Southey

data.quote: She bid me take love easy  as the leaves grow on the tree  But I  being young and foolish  with her would not agree.
data.author: William Butler Yeats

data.quote: Zeal is very blind  or badly regulated  when it encroaches upon the rights of others.
data.author: Pasquier Quesnel

data.quote: Blind zeal can only do harm.
data.author: Magnus Gottfried Lichtwer

data.quote: My zeal hath consumed me.
data.author: Bible

data.quote: To be furious in religion is to be irreligiously religious.
data.author: William Penn

data.quote: Here too, as in the Commune almost a century earlier, the struggle was articulated around the hope that 'the antithesis between the everyday and the Festival--whether of labour or of leisure--will no longer be a basis for society.
data.author: Tom McDonough, The Situationists and the City: A Reader

data.quote: The new towns of the 1950s and '60s were nothing less than the spatial translation of alienation and control and in these cities power increasingly could relinquish the old forms of advertising in favor of 'the simple organization of the spectacle of objects of consumption, which will only have consumable value illusory to the extent to which they will first of all have been objects of spectacle' -- to the extent, that is, they have first appeared on the television screen, which henceforth had to be seen as an urbanistic tool in its own right.
data.author: Tom McDonough, The Situationists and the City: A Reader

data.quote: One of my greatest obsessions is the lights of a city. Through my eyes there is nothing so delicious and rich and lovely.
data.author: K.B. Ezzell, Elysium

data.quote: As filthy as any night was, a New York City morning is always clean. The eyes get washed.Flowers in white deli buckets are replenished. The population bathes, in marble mausoleums of Upper East Side showers, or in Greenwich Village tubs, or in the sink of a Chinatown one-bedroom crammed with fifteen people. Some bar opens and the first song on the jukebox is Johnny Thunders, while bums pick up cigarette butts to see whats left to smoke. The smell of espresso and hot croissants. The weather vane squeaks in the sun. Pigeons are reborn out of the mouths of blue windows.
data.author: Jardine Libaire, White Fur

data.quote: A bus drives past and Im nauseated by a whiff of exhaust. Then rotting fish. The rancid stench of sewage. Is it garbage day? Im trapped in the pungent fog, in the dreary suburban-style shops, the rat race of city life. The city, even on the west coast, has the power to beat us down, to suck us of passion, to crush our dreams.
data.author: Shannon  Mullen, See What Flowers
data.category: city, imprisonment, rat-race, soul-crushing, vancouver, wild

data.quote: This is a little parable about cities and genres; how, while some of them lose their imaginative centrality, others take their place.
data.author: Amit Chaudhuri, Calcutta: Two Years in the City

data.quote: In the streets of Cecilia, an illustrious city, I met once a goatherd, driving a tinkling flock along the walls."Man blessed by heaven," he asked me, stopping, "can you tell me the name of the city in which we are?""May the gods accompany you!" I cried. "How can you fail to recognise the illustrious city of Cecilia?""Bear with me," that man answered. "I am a wandering herdsman. Sometimes my goats and I have to pass through cities; but we are unable to distinguish them. Ask me the names of the grazing lands: I know them all, the Meadow between the Cliffs, the Green Slope, the Shadowed Grass. Cities have no name for me: they are places without leaves, separating one pasture from another, and where the goats are frightened at street corners and scatter. The dog and I run to keep the flock together.""I am the opposite of you," I said. "I recognise only cities and cannot distinguish what is outside them. In uninhabited places each stone and each clump of grass mingles, in my eyes, with every stone and clump.
data.author: Italo Calvino, Invisible Cities

data.quote: She could hear her hair growing. It sounded like something crumbling. A burnt thing crumbling. Coal. Toast. Moths crisped on a light bulb. She remembered reading somewhere that even after people died, their hair and nails kept growing. Like starlight, travelling through the universe long after the stars themselves had died. Like cities. Fizzy, effervescent, simulating the illusion of life while the planet they had plundered died around them.
data.author: Arundhati Roy, The Ministry of Utmost Happiness

data.quote: She thought of the city at night, of cities at night. Discarded constellations of old stars, fallen from the sky, rearranged on Earth in patterns and pathways and towers. Invaded by weevils that have learned to walk upright.

data.quote: There are times when Los Angeles is the most magical city on Earth. When the Santa Ana winds sweep through and the air is warm and so, so clear. When the jacaranda trees bloom in the most brilliant lilac violet. When the ocean sparkles on a warm February day and you're pushing fine grains of sand through your bare toes while the rest of the country is hunkered down under blankets slurping soup. But other times, like when the jacaranda trees drop their blossoms in an eerie purple rain, Los Angeles feels like only a half-formed dream. Like perhaps the city was founded as a strip mall in the early 1970s and has no real reason to exist. An afterthought from the designer of some other, better city. A playground made only for attractive people to eat expensive salads.
data.author: Steven Rowley, Lily and the Octopus

data.quote: She knows she is in Chicago. But she does not yet realize that she is in Illinois.

data.quote: In our broad sweep, the city looks like a single gigantic creature - or more like a single collective entity created by many intertwining organism. Countless arteries stretch to the ends of its elusive body, circulating a continuous supply of fresh blood cells, sending out new data and collecting the old, sending out new consumables and collecting the old, sending out new contradictions and collecting the old. To the rhythm of its pulsing, all parts of the body flicker and flare up and squirm. Midnight is approaching, and while the peak of activity has passed, the basal metabolism that maintains life continues undiminished, producing the basso continuo of the city's moan, a monotonous sound that neither rises nor falls but is pregnant with foreboding.
data.author: Haruki Murakamiurakami

data.quote: The city had been built by people from innumerable elsewheres. It was a chaos of cultures ordered only by its long streets. It belonged to no one and never would, or maybe it was a million cities in one, unique to each of its inhabitants, belonging to whoever walked its streets.

data.quote: Allowing ourselves to become pure point of view, we hang in midair over the city. What we see now is a gigantic metropolis waking up. Commuter trains of many colors move in all directions, transporting people from place to place. Each of those under transport is a human being with a different face and mind, and at the same time each is a nameless part of the collective identity. Each is simultaneously a self-contained whole and a mere part. Handling this dualism of theirs skillfully and advantageously, they perform their morning rituals with deftness and precision: brushing teeth, shaving, tying neckties, applying lipstick. They check the morning news on TV, exchange words with their families, eat, defecate.
data.author: Haruki Murakami, After Dark

data.quote: An age-old city is like a pond. With its colours and reflections. Its chills and murk. Its ferment, its sorcery, its hidden life.A city is like a woman, with a womans desires and dislikes. Her abandon and restraint. Her reserve - above all, her reserve.To get to the heart of a city, to learn its most subtle secrets, takes infinite tenderness, and patience sometimes to the point of despair. It calls for an artlessly delicate touch, a more or less unconditional love. Over centuries.Time works for those who place themselves beyond time.Youre no true Parisian, you do not know your city, if you havent experienced its ghosts. To become imbued with shades of grey, to blend into the drab obscurity of blind spots, to join the clammy crowd that emerges, or seeps, at certain times of day from the metros, railway stations, cinemas or churches, to feel a silent and distant brotherhood with the lonely wanderer, the dreamer in his shy solitude, the crank, the beggar, even the drunk - all this entails a long and difficult apprenticeship, a knowledge of people and places that only years of patient observation can confer.
data.author: Jacques Yonnet

data.quote: And when spring comes to the City people notice one another in the road; notice the strangers with whom they share aisles and tables and the space where intimate garments are laundered. going in and out, in and out the same door, they handle the handle; on trolleys and park benches they settle thighs on a seat in which hundreds have done it too. Copper coins dropped in the palm have been swallowed by children and tested by gypsies, but its still money and people smile at that. Its the time of year when the City urges contradiction most, encouraging you to buy street food when you have no appetite at all; giving you a taste for a single room occupied by you alone as well as a craving to share it with someone you passed in the street. Really there is no contradictionrather its a condition; the range of what an artful City can do. What can beat bricks warming up to the sun? The return of awnings. The removal of blankets from horses backs. Tar softens under the heel and the darkness under bridges changes from gloom to cooling shade. After a light rain, when the leaves have come, tree limbs are like wet fingers playing in woolly green hair. Motor cars become black jet boxes gliding behind hoodlights weakened by mist. On sidewalks turned to satin figures move shoulder first, the crowns of their heads angled shields against the light buckshot that the raindrops are. The faces of children glimpsed at windows appear to be crying, but it is the glass pane dripping that makes it seem so.
data.author: Toni Morrison, Jazz

data.quote: The silhouettes of Lovat now dominated the skyline. Nine levels stretching skyward. Five hundred meters high at its apex. Thousands of sodium lamps twinkled in their recesses.Lovat was the oldest and largest city on the coast, and it showed its age by the haphazard mess it had become. Roads rose and dipped, elevators and staircases criss-crossed, and floors would end and then begin across the city leaving large empty spaces between levels.

data.quote: So now I lye by Day and toss or rave by Night, since the ratling and perpetual Hum of the Town deny me rest: just as Madness and Phrensy are the vapours which rise from the lower Faculties, so the Chaos of the Streets reaches up even to the very Closet here and I am whirl'd about by cries of Knives to Grind and Here are your Mouse-Traps. I was last night about to enter the Shaddowe of Rest when a Watch-man, half-drunken, thumps at the Door with his Past Three-a-clock and his Rainy Wet Morning. And when at length I slipp'd into Sleep I had no sooner forgot my present Distemper than I was plunged into a worse: I dreamd my self to be lying in a small place under ground, like unto a Grave, and my Body was all broken while others sung. And there was a Face that did so terrifie me that I had like to have expired in my Dream. Well, I will say no more.

data.quote: Three years in London had not changed Richard, although it had changed the way he perceived the city. Richard had originally imagined London as a gray city, even a black city, from pictures he had seen, and he was surprised to find it filled with color. It was a city of red brick and white stone, red buses and large black taxis, bright red mailboxes and green grassy parks and cemeteries.It was a city in which the very old and the awkwardly new jostled each other, not uncomfortably, but without respect; a city of shops and offices and restaurants and homes, of parks and churches, of ignored monuments and remarkably unpalatial palaces; a city of hundreds of districts with strange names - Crouch End, Chalk Farm, Earl's Court, Marble Arch - and oddly distinct identities; a noisy, dirty, cheerful, troubled city, which fed on tourists, needed them as it despised them, in which the average speed of transportation through the city had not increased in three hundred years, following five hundred years of fitful road-widening and unskillful compromises between the needs of traffic, whether horse-drawn, or, more recently, motorized, and the need of pedestrians; a city inhabited by and teeming with people of every color and manner and kind.
data.author: Neil Gaiman, Neverwhere

data.quote: A city finds its life through the humans who inhabit it. When they go, what is truly left? Just silent stones, witnesses to the history but mute in its telling, remaining thus while slowly turning to rubble. It saddens me that lifes moments are thus lost, that one cannot experience the past in the same rich vibrancy as the present. You live the moments and then relegate them to memory, now just two-dimensional shadows, pictures without depth, stripped of their purest emotion, their tactile connections no longer accessible. You try to recall, but can bring back only a fraction of the event lived. The rest is gone, never to be as full and complete as it was in that one place at that one time. That was what I thought as I studied these stone remains; that all the tangible things experienced here abide somewhere in time, but can never again be wholly re-animated, now just ghosts imbedded in the crumbling walls and in the fading memories of those who once lived here.
data.author: Michael  Puttonen, Disrupter

Rumour had it that, on stormy nights a century ago, they used to reach out, gouge holes in passing ships, and drag them down. Hundreds of wrecks lay buried in that glistening silt. The city's black heart had beaten strongly even then. There was one funeral director, supposedly, who used to put lamps out on the Fingers and lure ships to their doom.

data.quote: I'm in love with New York. It matches my mood. I'm not overwhelmed. It is the suitable scene for my ever ever heightened life. I love the proportions, the amplitude, the brilliance, the polish, the solidity. I look up at Radio City insolently and love it. It's all great, and Babylonian. Broadway at night. Cellophane. The newness. The vitality. True, it is only physical. But it's inspiring. Just bring your own contents, and you create a sparkle of the highest power. I'm not moved, not speechless. I stand straight, tough and I meet the impact. I feel the glow and the dancing in everything. The radio music in the taxis, scientific magic, which can all be used lyrically. That's my last word. Give New York to a poet. He can use it. It can be poetized. Or maybe that's mania of mine, to poetize. I live lightly, smoothly, actively, ears or eyes wide open, alert, oiled! I feel the glow and the dancing in every thing and the tempo is like that of my blood. I'm at once beyond, over and in New York, tasting it fully.
data.author: Anas Nin

data.quote: Every inch of space was used. As the road narrowed, signs receded upwards and changed to the vertical. Businesses simply soared from ground level and hung out vaster, more fascinatingly illuminated shingles than competitors. We were still in a traffic tangle, but now the road curved. Shops crowded the pavements and became homelier. Vegetables, spices, grocery produce in boxes or hanging from shop lintels, meats adangle - as always, my ultimate ghastliness - and here and there among the crowds the alarming spectacle of an armed Sikh, shotgun aslant, casually sitting at a bank entrance. And markets everywhere. To the right, cramped streets sloped down to the harbor. To the left, as we meandered along the tramlines through sudden dense markets of hawkers' barrows, the streets turned abruptly into flights of steps careering upwards into a bluish mist of domestic smoke, clouds of washing on poles, and climbing. Hong Kong had the knack of building where others wouldn't dare.
data.author: Jonathan Gash, Jade Woman

The horizon was the world's edge and there was nothing beyond it but mist and falling.Greaveburn stood alone on this little circle of earth, the river running around and into itself like a snake eating its tail. data.quote: Did you do this?There are other ways to beat someone than with fists. Radu poked her in the side with a finger.She surprised him by laughing. He had done something right!Then the lashings began.Radus smile wilted and died. He looked away. He was safe now. And Lada was proud of him, which had never happened before. He focused on that to ignore the sick feelings twisting his stomach as Aron and Andrei cried out in pain. data.quote: Something wonderful has happened to me. I was carried up into the seventh heaven. There all the gods sat assembled. By special grace I was granted the favor of a wish. "Will you," said Mercury, "have youth, or beauty, or power, or a long life, or the most beautiful maiden, or any of the other glories we have in the chest? Choose, but only one thing." For a moment I was at a loss. Then I addressed myself to the gods as follows: "Most honorable contemporaries, I choose this one thing, that I may always have the laugh on my side." Not one of the gods said a word, on the contrary, they all began to laugh. Hence, I concluded that my request was granted, and found that the gods knew how to express themselves with great taste; for it would hardly have been suitable for them to answer gravely: "It is granted thee.
data.author: Sren Kierkegaard, Either/Or: A Fragment of Life

data.quote: I finally made eye contact with the boy in the bed. He lay on his side, a tube in his nose and another in his vein. His cheeks were sunken, and his skin was ghostly pale. His hair might have been blond, but it was fading into a gray, making it hard to tell. The only part of this boy that held any life at all were his eyes, which brimmed with tears when he saw me.Kahlen?I sat still. These three people all called me by the same name, which sounded sort of like Katlyn and Ellen and made me believe that maybe they actually knew me.Where did you go? Where have you been? I thought you were dead. His chest worked overtime, trying to keep up with his mouth, spilling over with words.Can you get her a pen? Please? He lifted an arm weakly. It was all bone. I just need to know.A pen? I asked.Once again his eyes lit up.You can talk?I stared at this boy, at how he was overjoyed at one of the most basic things a person could do. So it would seem. I smiled.He flopped onto his back, laughing from his gut, and based on Julies tears, I was guessing shed been waiting a long time for that to come back.
data.author: Kiera Cass, The Siren

data.quote: You clumsy wenchGods above! Are you trying to rob me, girl? The nobleman seizes my wrist and yanks it from his pocket. My hand comes up with the pipe clenched in it. I stare at him, horrified.I . . .Ill have your head for this! the man rages. Ill have you whipped!***I got the pipe, I say, holding it up.He stares for a minute, blinking, and then bursts into laughter. A few curious deer stick their heads through the shrubs to see what the racket is. Aladdin doubles over, laughing loud enough to startle birds from the trees overhead, and after a moment, I start laughing too. I havent laughed this hard in a long, long while, and it feels wonderful. We sit on the grass and laugh until our faces are red and were out of breath.You are the worst thief I have ever seen, declares Aladdin.I dont know what youre talking about. I got it, didnt I?My grandmother could pick pockets better than that! Though thats not quite fair; my grandmother was the best pickpocket in Parthenia. She taught me all her tricks. Drove my mother crazy.

data.quote: When I watch a movie or read a book, be it a melodrama or horror, I always hate the female character... Well, most of the time I do.Why? Seriously? Romantic movie my ass, there's not anything romantic in letting go of someone when you can grab them with both of your hands. That is not romantic, THAT is stupid.In another movie the girl storms out, never hearing the guy out, just like in that one book I've been reading recently, "Tangled". Now this is an issue with most of the books and chick-flicks. Like why? Why won't you stop a minute, take a deep breath, count to ten and listen to the guy. Only after that, for God's sake, say fuck you then Namaste and then walk away while swaying your hips like there is no tomorrow? Let them know what they will be missing for the rest of their lives.In some other movies I hate the main female character because of the scriptwriters. The girl somehow always appears in front of the guy out of nowhere. Like he can be walking down the street and then boom! ABRACADABRA! The main girl bumps into him in NYC out of all places. They make it seem like whatever they do their steps always bring them back to each other. Dumb, I know.

I saw that the meaning of life was to secure a livelihood, and that its goal was to attain a high position; that loves rich dream was marriage with an heiress; that friendships blessing was help in financial difficulties; that wisdom was what the majority assumed it to be; that enthusiasm consisted in making a speech; that it was courage to risk the loss of ten dollars; that kindness consisted in saying, You are welcome, at the dinner table; that piety consisted in going to communion once a year. This I saw, and I laughed.

data.quote: I break out laughing. I frown.I yell and scream. Sometimes,if one jokes and giggles,one causes war.So I hide how tickled I am.Tears well up in my eyes.My body is a large city.Much grieving in one sector.I live in another part.Lakewater.Something on fire over here.I am sour when you are sour,sweet when you are sweet.You are my face and my back.Only through you can I knowthis back-scratching pleasure.Now people the likes of you and Icome clapping, inventing dances,climbing into this high meadow.I am a spoiled parrot who eats only candy.I have no interest in bitter food.Some have been given harsh knowledge. Not I.Some are lame and jerking along.I am smooth and glidingly quick.Their road is full of washed-out placesand long inclines. Mine isroyally level, effortless.The huge Jerusalem mosque stands inside me,and women full of light.Laughter leaps out.It is the nature of the rose to laugh.It cannot help but laugh.

data.quote: Feeling the slight tremor of his fingers against her skin, Daisy was emboldened to remark, Ive never been attracted to tall men before. But you make me feel If you dont keep quiet, he interrupted curtly, Im going to strangle you. Daisy felt silent, listening to the rhythm of his breath as it turned deeper, less controlled. By contrast his fingers became more certain in their task, working along the row of pearls until her dress gaped open and the sleeves slipped from her shoulders. Where is it? he asked. The key?His tone was deadly. Yes, Daisy. The key. It fell inside my corset. Which means Ill have to take that off too. There was no reaction to the statement, no sound or movement. Daisy twisted to glance at Matthew. He seemed dazed. His eyes looked unnaturally blue against the flush on his face. She realized he was occupied with a savage inner battle to keep from touching her. Feeling hot and prickly with embarrassment, Daisy pulled her arms completely out of her sleeves. She worked the dress over her hips, wriggling out of the filmy white layers, letting them slide to the floor in a heap. Matthew stared at the discarded dress as if it were some kind of exotic fauna he had never seen before. Slowly his eyes returned to Daisy, and an incoherent protest came from his throat as she began to unhook her corset. She felt shy and wicked, undressing in front of him. But she was encouraged by the way he seemed unable to tear his gaze from each newly revealed inch of pale skin. When the last metal hook came apart, she tossed the web of lace and stays to the floor. All that remained over her breasts was a crumpled chemise. The key had dropped into her lap. Closing her fingers around the metal object, she risked a cautious glance at Matthew. His eyes were closed, his forehead scored with furrows of pained concentration. This isnt going to happen, he said, more to himself than to her. Daisy leaned forward to tuck the key into his coat pocket. Gripping the hem of her chemise, she stripped it over her head. A tingling shock chased over her naked upper body. She was so nervous that her teeth had begun to chatter. I just took my chemise off, she said. Dont you want to look? No. But his eyes had opened, and his gaze found her small, pink-tipped breasts, and the breath hissed through his clenched teeth. He sat without moving, staring at her as she untied his cravat and unbuttoned the layers of his waistcoat and shirt. She blushed everywhere but continued doggedly, rising to her knees to tug the coat from his shoulders. He moved like a dreamer, slowly pulling his arms from the coat sleeves and waistcoat. Daisy pushed his shirt open with awkward determination, her gaze drinking in the sight of his chest and torso. His skin gleamed like heavy satin, stretched taut over broad expanses of muscle. She touched the powerful vault of his ribs, trailing her fingertips to the rippled tautness of his midriff. Suddenly Matthew caught her hand, seemingly undecided whether to push it away or press it closer. Her fingers curled over his. She stared into his dilated blue eyes. Matthew, she whispered. Im here. Im yours. I want to do everything youve ever imagined doing with me. He stopped breathing. His will foundered and collapsed, and suddenly nothing mattered except the demands of a desire that had been denied too long. With a rough groan of surrender, he lifted her onto his lap.
data.author: Lisa Kleypas, Scandal in Spring
